title: My first novel is 60,000 words. Is it too short? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s important to look at the historical context of publishing in considering your question. For most of publishing history (up until not too many years ago), it was necessary for books to be a certain length to be economically viable to publish. Cover design, interior design, distribution set-up, promotion & publicity, contract execution, offset pre-press and creating press plates… all of these things (and more) were basically the same cost whether the book was 50 or 300 pages. However, a 300-page book could command a higher price, which meant that the economics favored longer books from the publisher’s perspective. Thus, otherwise arbitrary benchmarks came about — “a novel has to be X length in words”; the Library of Congress only considers a book a “book” if it’s longer than 50 pages; etc. None of this is relevant now. We have the ability to economically publish books of almost any length thanks to digital printing, self-publishing, print-on-demand, and online sales (primarily Amazon). As long as your audience thinks the price is fair for the quality of the story (or information) you deliver, the length doesn’t matter. Thus, we have Nobel-prize-winning José Saramago’s The Tale of the Unknown Island, which clocks in at a mere 62 pages including all the front matter and three blank back pages, and is highly acclaimed and popular. (It isn’t print-on-demand, but it could be if you weren’t a Nobel-prize-winning author.) So, your novel of 60,000 words isn’t “too short” if it successfully tells its story and sells for a fair price… but nor would it be at 25,000 or 30,000 or 40,000 words. Concern yourself with quality, not quantity. When 6′5″ and long-legged Abe Lincoln was reportedly asked, “How long should a man’s legs be?” he’s said to have answered, “Long enough to reach the ground.”

The rule of thumb for length of a novel is 60,000 words, approximately, so you’re right there. However, I suggest you ask yourself a few questions, which might affect the length going forward. You haven’t shared any details, so I don’t know the genre or subject matter. Therefore, these comments are blind. Editing can either add or subtract words. In some cases, I’ve discovered that I hadn’t properly set up a scene and needed precisely placed paragraphs earlier in the book to provide justification/orientation. Example: I had a character who showed up late in one of my novels. An early reader told me I hadn’t earned her appearance, and he was right. I added scenes with her in several spots earlier in the book. 1,700 words added. In many cases, I find duplication and remove the offending prose. Have your characters struggled to reach their objectives? Any story that allows a protagonist to go from Point A to Point B easily isn’t very interesting. Adding failed attempts or difficult situations will enhance the story and lengthen the work. Have you provided sufficient backstory, peppered throughout? Can a reader see the setting from the way you’ve described the locations, or from the way your characters have interacted with their environment? Those are great opportunities to appropriately lengthen your work and give your readers a better sense of place.

It’s hard to say. Is it for children/YA? Is it very literary? The fact is that while Google will probably tell you that 50–60K words is a novel it’s not one that you are likely to get published. But it’s not so far away! Did anyone read it yet? Get advice and input from people you trust (not the ones who will just pat your back!) and you may find there are problems with the novel that require rework that will add the words you need. Roughly another 10K words would make it suitable length for publishing in many genres (detective, romance etc.) If it’s epic fantasy or a thriller though you are probably 20–40K words short and that might be a problem. Is there a hidden third act? Something that could logically happen after what you currently think is the end of your novel that would be exciting, surprising and make it a better read? Good luck!

60,000 words is never short for a novel. Word count never decide the success of a novel, but the quality of the work does. Novels like The Alchemist, The White Tiger are just 200-250 pages. On the other hand, the novels like A Song of Ice and Fire series, and Harry Potter series, are 400-800 pages. All the above novels are immensely successful. They have created a legacy, even after a century the readers will remember them. Again, 60,000 works in never short for a novel. If you are about to publish your novel, go ahead without any doubts. Trust in your work and publish it. If you have already published your novel, market it well, make it visible to more readers. Wish you a great success for your work!

60,000 words is pretty short, but it depends heavily on the genre and target market. For science fiction or fantasy, 60k is going to be a very rough sell (though there are still famous examples of SFF books of that length). By contrast, it’s probably fine for something like romance or thriller, as those are often quite trim. Similarly, 60k is short for adult fiction in any genre, but probably okay in young adult - YA novels are usually about 10k or so shorter than adult novels in the same genre.

First off congratulations! A 60K word First Novel is a fantastic thing. My first was closer to 200K. Parred back to 95K after editing. Most first novels are way over the 100K but should be in the 60K range. As far as marketability 60K is a respectable novel. If you’ve done your first novel at 60K and it is in fact a full novel, something that a beta reader can tell you. Then you’ve overcome two of beginning writers problems. Writing a book and making it concise. Good Job.

My first novel is just 35,000 words, and second is 40,000 words. You can finish both the novels in four days. In both the novels, the character and plots are nice and I have edited it several times. It doesn't matter how long your novel is, what matters the most is, is your story, good enough to read? But you have written till 60000 word of your novel, now, I congratulate you for that one. But when you sit for editing it, you’ll be cutting most of the paragraphs and even pages. But, make sure that you tell a nice story, without boring the readers of your novel. Make sure each scene, is described in a certain way, not more nor less. Still, keep up the good work, as a first time, writer, you wrote 60000 words of your novel. Its really good…

No. It is fine. Some posters will make snarky remarks but fuck them. Here are mine (published traditionally, the first two are out and have each won two awards). K-Town Confidential published at 82,000 words. Original ms. was more than double that. Kat & Maus 52,000 words Untitled #3 will be published between 55 and 65,000. Untitled #4 will be published between 50 and 55,000. 3 and 4 are both YA. What matter is that your book is professionally structured and edited and most of all — doesn’t suck.

Knowing nothing else, no, it squeaks in at the bare minimum word-count for a novel in general. Specific genres might have other requirements, though. For example, if this is an epic fantasy or science fiction piece, it’s probably 30–60k words too short. But if it’s a cozy romance, you probably can’t get away with more than fifteen thousand additional words or it becomes “too long.” Research novel lengths specific to your genre.

Not at all. The cut off length for any novel is 40,000 words. Anything less than 40,000 will be considered a novella, not a novel. Secondly, different genres have different range of word length, you should search for it online. Then, anything between 40,000 to 60,000 word length is good for any novel provided you have done the editing for it.

The question should be have you told the story you mean to tell, about how your protagonist changed? Novel length varies by publisher, by the type of story, by the number of subplots, by the duration of the story, and by the skill of the writer. It all depends on whether you and your publisher feel it is complete.

If an agent doesn’t represent you because a book is a few thousand words short, they are not good agents. I could make a huge list of books that didn’t sell well that are very long or just the “right” length, and short books that have been on the best seller list for months and years.

The number of words does not determine whether it’s too anything. The number of words just determines what it is. 60,000 words is a good average length especially for a first novel. Too long and the publishers would not read it. Less than 40,000 words and you are looking at a more difficult and less profitable market. If you’re happy go with it.

Too short for what? It depends on what publishing house you want to offer your novel. For example, the publisher who publishes my books stipulates 55,00 words for certain kinds of novels, and 100,00 for others. You should check first before you submit.
No, that's great! For a book to be considered a novel it has to be 40000 to 70000 words long, so for your first novel that is wonderful.
